newsitem.title: TAIWAN: President up on chain store listing.
newsitem.headline: President up on chain store listing.

text.p: Taiwan's food giant President Enterprises Corp rose at mid-morning on Friday after the country's securities watchdog approved listing of its money-making chain store subsidiary, brokers said.
After 75 minutes at 0215 GMT, President was up T$2 or 4.08 percent to T$51.
"This is a long-awaiting bullish news for President Enterprises," said Alex Yang, an analyst for National Securities.
"President's profit will receive a significant boost after selling the chain store shares," Yang said.
The Secuities and Exchange Commission approved on Wednesday the chain store's listing after a half-year delay.
President Chain Store, which runs the 7-Eleven franchise in Taiwan, had been scheduled for listing at the end of 1996. But an inquiry on insider trading allegations delayed the listing plan.
The chain store is the largest of all similar operations in Taiwan.
The chain store is expected to offer 43.2 million shares, half of which would be offered through underwriters and the other half through auctions, brokers said.
Brokers estimated the initial offered price would be set at around T$90.
